If a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g., if it crosses a mountain range or a river, or if it settles on a new island, so that it cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations in order to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
With time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations will look so different that they can no longer be classified as the same species.
We call this process specialization, which simply means the emergence of new species. Specialization is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely beyond the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
It can be said that the automobile is indispensable for the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network is not economically viable for a small number of cars. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.
The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new techniques in the medical field to repair damaged bodies.

After his farewell by the Congress on 4 July, a handwritten draft, signed by the Congress President John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson, was sent a few blocks away to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as the "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived the passage of time.

Content theories concentrate on finding what moves or appeals to people.

At the other end of the spectrum, one becomes an unrecognizable individual who does everything differently from the team and takes everything for themselves.

Virtual teams are managed according to the same excellence standards as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often have the function of a contact point for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members, because their teams meet in different time zones that the local leadership may not have considered.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto 1989, p. 109) is also a unique component of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the leadership team, to whom each member reports. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.

KI (Künstliche Intelligenz) is often associated with Science Fiction, but is an important branch of computer science that deals with behavior, learning and the adaptation of machines to intelligent behavior.
Research in the field of AI includes the creation of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behavior.
Examples of such skills are control, the setting of strategies and time plans, the ability to answer customer questions and diagnoses, as well as handwriting, voice and face recognition.
Such things have become independent disciplines that focus on finding solutions to real life problems.

Today, the KI system is widely used in the fields of business, medicine, engineering and the military and has also been incorporated into numerous software applications for home computers and video games.
Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her pupils to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual field trips are a technological solution. Students can view museum exhibits, visit an aquarium, or admire works of art from their classroom.
Sharing a virtual field trip is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Because students are often a very critical audience, the blogger makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to inspire interest in the audience inspires the students to write intelligently and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires cooperation and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; through the active reaction to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of other authors and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)

The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was named Casablanca by Spanish traders who set up trading posts there.

Goma is a tourist town in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, especially the city center.
While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside of Goma should be carefully planned to keep abreast of the ongoing fighting in the province of North Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo and for some of the cheapest gorilla tracking tours in Africa.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is in the northeast of South Africa. It borders on Mozambique in the east, on Zimbabwe in the north and on the Crocodile River in the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km² and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance fees.
It may also be worthwhile to purchase a Wild Card which grants access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island is the namesake of the territory of Hong Kong and stands at the center of many tourists' interests.

The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch over 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans have been a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 meters high, their length is 378 meters and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 meters.
The clearance height under the bridge is 15 meters. The construction works were completed in August 2011, but the road was not opened until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will then be completed.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group that inhabited the present-day East Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunters who also practiced subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also the homeland of other groups of indigenous tribes, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of the Spanish conquerors with the indigenous groups.
The Spaniards began the colonization period, which lasted three centuries.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), whose value is in line with the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the island, which is located opposite the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley credit cards. US dollars are often accepted.

Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the remote islands, but British and US currency may be accepted; it is advisable to enquire in advance with the owners as to which payment method is accepted.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside of the islands themselves, so you should exchange your money before you leave the islands.

German baked goods are pretty tasty. In Bavaria they're pretty filling and varied, just as they are in the southern neighbor Austria.

Indonesian cuisine consists of a wide variety of regional dishes using a mixture of Indian, Chinese, Japanese, Middle Eastern, European, and indigenous influences.
When the term is used without further attributes, it generally refers to the food that originated in the central and eastern parts of the main island of Java.

The cuisine of Java, which is now widespread throughout the island group, offers a wide variety of simply spiced dishes. The Javanese prefer to use peanuts, chilis, sugar (especially Javanese coconut sugar) and a variety of aromatic spices as flavorings.
Steigbügel are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet might get caught in them.
If a rider falls off a horse and gets caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along, if the horse runs. To reduce this risk as much as possible, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a relatively narrow sole.
In addition, some saddles, especially English saddles, are equipped with safety buckles that allow a stirrup leather to fall if pulled backward by a falling rider.

Downhill sports like skiing and snowboarding are popular sports in which you fasten skis or a snowboard to your feet and slide down a snow-covered slope.
Skiing is a popular travel activity with many enthusiasts, sometimes referred to as "ski bums," who plan their entire vacation around skiing at a particular location.
The idea of skiing is very old – cave paintings with depictions of skiers go back to 5000 BC!
The origins of skiing as a sport go back at least to the 17th century, and in 1861 the first recreational ski club in Australia was opened by Norwegians.
Hiking with a backpack: This activity is also called ski touring or ski hiking.
It resembles alpine touring skiing or mountaineering, but does not necessarily include it, as the latter involves steep terrain and requires more robust ski equipment and boots.
Consider the ski route as a comparable hiking route.
With good conditions, you can cover greater distances than when hiking – only very rarely will you reach the speed of cross-country skiing without a heavy backpack.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but it has many independent countries. Normally, you would have to apply for visas and go through passport control several times if you wanted to travel through several countries.
The Schengen Area functions in this respect somewhat like a country.
As long as you stay in this zone, you can normally cross the border without having to go through passport control again.
You don't have to apply for a visa for each of the Schengen countries individually, which saves time, money and bureaucracy.

Storm is the collective term for any dangerous weather phenomenon with the potential to cause damage, severe social disruption or the loss of human life.
Weather can happen anywhere in the world and there are different kinds of it, depending on the geography, topography, and atmospheric conditions.
Strong winds, hail, excessive rainfall, and forest fires are forms and effects of weather, as are thunderstorms, tornadoes, flash floods, and whirlwinds.
Regional and seasonal weather phenomena include blizzards, snowstorms, dust storms and hailstorms.
Travellers are warned to watch out for any kind of weather that affects their area, as this can affect all their travel plans.

Rip currents are the returning current of broken waves at the shore, often at reefs or similar.
Due to the underwater topography, the return flow is concentrated in a few deeper areas and a fast current can form there.
Most drownings occur through exhaustion while trying to swim against the current, which proves impossible.
If you come out of the current, swimming back is not more difficult than usual.
Try to get somewhere where you won't be caught again. Alternatively, if you have the skills and if you have been caught, perhaps you should wait for rescue.

Japanese work culture is hierarchical and more formal than what Westerners may be used to.
Suits are part of the standard business attire and colleagues address each other by their family names or job titles.
The harmony at the workplace is of great importance, with the focus more on group performance than on praise for individual performance.
Employees often have to get the approval of their supervisors for every decision they make and it is expected that they will follow the instructions of their bosses without question.
